title: Randomised, Double-blind, Parallel-group, Placebo-controlled, Fixed-dose Study of Idalopirdine in Patients With Mild - Moderate Alzheimer's Disease Treated With Donepezil
description_brief: To establish efficacy of idalopirdine as adjunctive therapy to donepezil for symptomatic treatment of patients with mild-to-moderate Alzheimer's disease (AD).
description_detailed: The study consisted of a screening period (up to 2-week period from screening to randomization), a 24-week double-blind treatment period with placebo or idalopirdine 30 mg/day or 60 mg/day as adjunctive therapy to donepezil 10 mg/day, and a 4-week safety follow-up period following study completion or withdrawal from treatment.

measures.title: MMSE total score at screening
measures.description: The Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) is an 11-item test to assess the cognitive aspects of mental function. The subtests assess orientation, memory, attention, language, and visual construction. The scores for each item is dichotomous (1 = response is correct, 0 = response is incorrect). Total score of the 11 items ranges from 0 to 30 (higher score indicates lower deficit).

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Cognition
outcomeMeasures.description:
Change from baseline to Week 24 in Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-cognitive subscale (ADAS-cog) total score.

The Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale - Cognitive subscale (ADAS-cog) is a 11-item neuropsychological test that assess the severity of cognitive impairment. The items determine the patient's orientation, memory, language, and praxis. Total score of the 11 items range from 0 to 70 (lower score indicates lower cognitive impairment).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All patients who took at least one dose of placebo or idalopirdine, and who had a valid baseline assessment and at least on valid post-baseline assessment of the primary outcome measure in the 24-week treatment period (Full-analysis Set). For secondary outcome measures, the number of participants who had the respective outcome measure assessed.

analyses.groupDescription: For demonstrating efficacy of a dose, change in cognition (ADAS-cog) and either change in daily functioning (ADCS-ADL23) or change in global clinical impression (ADCS-CGIC) had to show statistically significant favourable differences compared to placebo at Week 24. Multiple testing procedures were used to control the overall type 1 error at 5%. The null hypothesis of no difference in mean change from baseline in ADAS-cog total score at Week 24 was tested for each dose at significance level 2.5%.
analyses.statisticalComment: Treatment, country, MMSE stratum, week as fixed effects, baseline score, treatment-by-week, MMSE stratum-by-week, and baseline-by-week interactions
analyses.estimateComment: A negative mean difference indicates a treatment effect in favour of idalopirdine

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Daily Functioning
outcomeMeasures.description:
Change from baseline to Week 24 in Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study - Activities of Daily Living Inventory (ADCS-ADL23) total score.

The Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study - Activities of Daily Living (ADCS-ADL23) is a 23-item clinician-rated inventory to assess activities of daily living (conducted with a caregiver or informant). Each item comprises a series of hierarchical sub-questions, ranging from the highest level of independent performance to a complete loss for each activity. Total score of the 23 items ranges from 0 to 78 (higher score indicates lower disability).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All patients who took at least one dose of placebo or idalopirdine, and who had a valid baseline assessment and at least on valid post-baseline assessment of the primary outcome measure in the 24-week treatment period (Full-analysis Set). For secondary outcome measures, the number of participants who had the respective outcome measure assessed.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Global Impression
outcomeMeasures.description:
Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study - Clinical Global Impression of Change (ADCS-CGIC) score at Week 24.

The Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study - Clinical Global Impression of Change is a semi-structured interview to assess clinically relevant changes in patients with AD. The items determine cognition, behavior, social and daily functioning. Severity at baseline is rated on a 7-point scale from 1 (normal, not ill at all) to 7 (among the most extremely ill patients). The clinically relevant change from baseline is rated on a 7-point scale from 1 (marked improvement) to 7 (marked worsening).

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Behavioural Disturbance
outcomeMeasures.description:
Change from baseline to Week 24 in Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI) total score.

The Neuropsychiatric Inventory is a 12-item structured interview with a caregiver to assess behavioural disturbances. The NPI comprises 10 behavioural and 2 neurovegetative items. Each item consists of a screening question and several sub-questions that are rated no (not present) or yes (present). Each item is rated for frequency (a 4-point scale from 1 \[occasionally\] to 4 \[very frequent\]) and severity (a 3-point scale from 1 \[mild\] to 3 \[marked\]). The total NPI score is the frequency ratings multiplied by the severity ratings and ranges from 0 to 144 (higher score indicates worse outcome).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All patients who took at least one dose of placebo or idalopirdine, and who had a valid baseline assessment and at least on valid post-baseline assessment of the primary outcome measure in the 24-week treatment period (Full-analysis Set). For secondary outcome measures, the number of participants who had the respective outcome measure assessed.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Individual Behavioural Disturbance Items
outcomeMeasures.description:
Change in single NPI item scores at Week 24.

The Neuropsychiatric Inventory is a 12-item structured interview with a caregiver to assess behavioural disturbances. The NPI comprises 10 behavioural and 2 neurovegetative items. Each item consists of a screening question and several sub-questions that are rated no (not present) or yes (present). Each item is then rated for frequency (a 4-point scale from 1 \[occasionally\] to 4 \[very frequent\]) and severity (a 3-point scale from 1 \[mild\] to 3 \[marked\]). Total score for each single NPI item ranges from 0-12 (frequency multiplied by severity), where higher scores represent worse outcome.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All patients who took at least one dose of placebo or idalopirdine, and who had a valid baseline assessment and at least on valid post-baseline assessment of the primary outcome measure in the 24-week treatment period (Full-analysis Set). outcomeMeasures.title: Change in NPI Anxiety Item Score in Patients With an NPI Anxiety Item Score of at Least 2 at Baseline
outcomeMeasures.description:
Change from baseline to Week 24 in NPI anxiety item score in patients with an NPI anxiety item score of at least 2 at baseline

The Neuropsychiatric Inventory is a 12-item structured interview with a caregiver to assess behavioural disturbances. The NPI comprises 10 behavioural and 2 neurovegetative items. Each item consists of a screening question and several sub-questions that are rated no (not present) or yes (present). Each item is then rated for frequency (a 4-point scale from 1 \[occasionally\] to 4 \[very frequent\]) and severity (a 3-point scale from 1 \[mild\] to 3 \[marked\]). The total score for the NPI anxiety item ranges from 0-12 (frequency multiplied by severity), where a higher score represents a worse outcome.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Health-related Quality of Life (EQ-5D) Utility Score
outcomeMeasures.description:
Change from baseline to Week 24 in EuroQol 5-dimensional (EQ-5D) utility score

The EQ-5D is a patient-reported assessment that measures the patient's well-being. It consists of an utility score based on 5 descriptive items (mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort, and depression/anxiety) and a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS). Each descriptive item is rated on a 3-point index ranging from 1 (no problems) to 3 (extreme problems) that is used for calculating a single summary index (from 0 to 1). A higher EQ-5D score indicates a worse outcome.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All patients who took at least one dose of placebo or idalopirdine, and who had a valid baseline assessment and at least on valid post-baseline assessment of the primary outcome measure in the 24-week treatment period (Full-analysis Set). outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Health-related Quality of Life (EQ-5D VAS)
outcomeMeasures.description:
Change from baseline to Week 24 in EQ-5D Visual Analogue Scale (EQ-5D VAS).

The EQ-5D is a patient-reported assessment that measures the patient's well-being. It consists of an utility score based on 5 descriptive items (mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort, and depression/anxiety) and a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS). The VAS ranges from 0 (worst imaginable health state) to 100 (best imaginable health state).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All patients who took at least one dose of placebo or idalopirdine, and who had a valid baseline assessment and at least on valid post-baseline assessment of the primary outcome measure in the 24-week treatment period (Full-analysis Set). adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: Baseline to end of study at Week 24
adverseEventsModule.description: Treatment-Emergent Adverse Events are reported in this section

seriousEvents.organSystem: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)
Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

drug: Idalopirdine (Lu AE58054) — selective 5‑HT6 receptor antagonist (small molecule)
explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests idalopirdine as an adjunct to donepezil for symptomatic treatment of mild-to-moderate Alzheimer’s disease. Idalopirdine is a small‑molecule, selective 5‑HT6 (serotonin) receptor antagonist developed to improve cognition (symptomatic/cognitive enhancement), not to directly target amyloid or tau pathology. citeturn0search5turn0search0

Act: Extracted trial details — intervention = idalopirdine (Lu AE58054) added to donepezil; comparator = placebo; intended effect = symptomatic cognitive improvement in mild-to-moderate AD. Phase II reported cognitive benefit when added to donepezil, while the subsequent large Phase III program (multiple 24‑week, fixed‑dose studies) did not demonstrate consistent efficacy. citeturn0search0turn0search2turn0search1

Reflect: Classification check — according to the provided category definitions, idalopirdine is a small‑molecule aimed at improving cognition (a symptomatic/cognitive enhancer) rather than a biologic or a small molecule that targets core Alzheimer pathology; therefore the correct category is 'cognitive enhancer'. No meaningful ambiguity in the description that would point to disease‑modifying intent or neuropsychiatric symptom targeting. citeturn0search5turn0search2

Web search results used (key sources): Lancet Neurology Phase II report of idalopirdine showing cognitive benefit as adjunct to donepezil; pharmacology papers showing high‑affinity selective 5‑HT6 antagonism and effects on monoamines; summaries and publications reporting the Phase III STAR/STARSHINE program and subsequent negative Phase III findings. citeturn0search0turn0search5turn0search2turn0search1
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational drug idalopirdine (Lu AE58054) is a selective antagonist of the serotonin 5‑HT6 receptor — a neurotransmitter (serotonin) receptor implicated in cognition — and was tested as an adjunctive symptomatic/cognitive enhancer to donepezil rather than as an anti-amyloid or anti-tau disease‑modifying agent. citeturn0search2turn0search1

Act: Extracted details from the trial description and literature: intervention = idalopirdine (selective 5‑HT6 antagonist) added to background donepezil (an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor) with the intended effect of symptomatic cognitive improvement in mild–moderate AD. Phase II (LADDER) reported cognitive benefit when added to donepezil, while the larger Phase III STAR program failed to demonstrate consistent efficacy. Based on these facts, the most specific CADRO match is D) Neurotransmitter Receptors. citeturn1search3turn1search8turn1search4

Reflect: Verification — 5‑HT6 is a serotonin (5‑HT) receptor, which falls squarely under the CADRO category for neurotransmitter receptors (D). The trial tests a symptomatic cognitive enhancer acting via a neurotransmitter receptor rather than targeting amyloid, tau, inflammation, synaptic growth factors, or other CADRO categories; therefore D) Neurotransmitter Receptors is the appropriate classification. Key supporting web sources are listed below. citeturn0search6turn0search5
Web search results (key sources cited above):

- Pharmacology and mechanism: idalopirdine is a high‑affinity selective 5‑HT6 (serotonin) receptor antagonist; preclinical work shows effects on monoamines/glutamate relevant to cognition. citeturn0search2turn0search1
- Phase II clinical evidence: LADDER (Lancet Neurology / PubMed) reported cognitive improvement when idalopirdine (90 mg/day) was added to donepezil in moderate AD. citeturn1search0turn1search3

- Phase III outcomes: The STAR/STARSHINE/STARBEAM program (large Phase III studies) did not meet prespecified efficacy endpoints; the phase III program failed to replicate the phase II benefit. citeturn1search4turn1search6
